Dear Holly Anderton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Repeat violations
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A wrapped a cord around her neck last night before bed
around 8pm and had it on the entire night until this morning when
she went to school. Youth A has marks on her neck from this
event. Youth A went to school where they noticed the marks.
According to staff, she should have been checked by staff every
10 minutes throughout the night.
Investigation Administrator 1/Complainant 1 was interviewed via phone, on
5/18/2023. She reported being aware of the allegations and Youth
A is currently lodged in a psychiatric hospital because of self-
harming behavior.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
5/18/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
knowing of the incident and understanding school officials
observed bruising on Youth A’s neck. Youth A told school officials
she had attempted to harm herself overnight. The school
2

contacted the facility with Therapist and Staff 2 going to the school
to take Youth A to the hospital where she was admitted.
Administrator 2 also reported this is the second attempt at self-
harm resulting in Youth A being admitted to a psychiatric hospital.
Because of the prior attempt at self-harm and her return to the
facility on 5/1/23, Youth A was on increase supervision involving
five-minute room checks. Because of her positive behavior
changes, this was changed to ten-minute checks on 5/12/23. The
safety plan outlining this information is reviewed below.
Administrator 2 was interviewed again via phone, on 6/1/2023.
He reported Youth A had returned to the facility on 5/24/2023 but
went AWOL from school on 5/31/2023. Youth A is currently lodged
in the hospital again waiting transfer to a psychiatric hospital. He
will provide updated information on the situation. Administrator 2
reported when staff are documenting on the precautions flow
sheet, they will only document if finding and removing something
from Youth A’s room when they conduct room checks.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
5/18/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
understanding the purpose of the interview and did not find out
about Youth A’s self-harming behaviors until the next day. She
reported being the third shift staff present on the night of 5/14/23
and responsible for Youth A the night Youth A had the cord
around her neck. Staff 1 completed the room checks “no more
than ten-minutes apart and variable”. Staff 1 described her room
checks, “Youth A looked like she was sleeping, and her blanket
was covering her neck. I could see her whole face and I watched
for her chest to rise and fall so I knew she was breathing.
Sometimes she would move her head side to side, and I would
watch her for a several seconds before leaving the room.” Staff 1
reported Youth A was asleep when she started her shift, and she
was not informed of any situation during the day with Youth A that
would cause concern. Staff 1 acknowledge Youth A was on
precautions because of her risk for self-harm. Staff 1 also reported
Youth A was awake at 6:30 am but when asked if she wanted to
get up for a shower, “Youth A acted like she was sleeping and
refused to respond”. Staff 1 checked on her every ten-minutes
before changing to five-minute checks. Staff 2 attempted to get
Youth A to get up but failed in her attempts. She described her
attempts as raising her voice, turning on the lights, and shaking
the bed. Both Staff 1 and Staff 2 shook the bed and Youth A finally
responded twenty minutes later. Youth A refused to take a shower
around 7:00 am. Staff 1 reported not observing any marks on
Youth A and Youth A said nothing about feeling upset or injured.
3

Staff 1 did notice Youth A appeared to be moving slower than
normal before Staff 2 took Youth A to school. Staff 1 reported
never being asked to check Youth A’s neck while she was
sleeping but was asked to remove cords from her room following
the early incident that occurred on 4/23/23. Following the first
incident, she was required to take all cords from Youth A’s room
and place them in a locked room. She was not required to check
Youth A’s personal belongings and believed the second shift staff
would check because Youth A was always in bed when she began
third shift. Because Staff 1 was also working at the time of the first
incident she gave the following report regarding that situation
which occurred the night of 4/23/23. Youth A was upset after
being told “no” by a supervisor and went into her room. Staff 1
gave her a few minutes of alone time before knocking on the door
and requesting to enter. Youth A informed her through the door
that she was changing and after hearing a nose, Staff 1 went into
the room to find Youth A laying on the floor face down. Staff 1
asked Youth A if she needed anything and Youth A did not
respond. Youth A’s hair was covering her neck causing Staff 1 not
to observe her neck. Staff 1 heard Youth A grasping for air and
because she was not sure of the reason for this grasping, she
located and informed Staff 5 who came into the room and
discovered the cord, quickly removing it from Youth A’s neck. Staff
5 had called for the shift supervisor. Staff 1 found Youth A laying
on the floor around 11:30 to 11:45 pm and Staff 5 removed the
cord around midnight. Staff 1 reported believing Youth A was
faking a seizure because “she does stuff like that often”. Staff 1
also reported the facility is aware of Youth A’s “faking seizures”
and it has been “medically proven” that she engages in these
behaviors. Youth A had tied a computer cord around her neck
resulting in her first admission to a psychiatric hospital.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
5/18/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Therapist was
also interviewed via phone on 6/5/23. She reported being
assigned as Youth A’s primary therapist when Youth A was placed
at the facility. She also reported following the first incident on
4/23/23, a safety plan was developed when Youth A returned to
the facility on 5/1/23 that included the following conditions. Staff
are to review Youth A’s goals twice a day and debrief with Youth A
how she will accomplish the goals at the beginning of the day and
what progress she made just before bedtime. Staff were to
conduct five-minute bedroom checks and always keep within
arm’s length of Youth A apart from her using the bathroom. Staff
are also to report to the clinical team if they notice any changes in
Youth A’s moods. She did admit there was nothing in the safety
4

plan about checking Youth A’s neck when doing room checks.
Youth A was stepped down on 5/12/23 from the 5-minute checks
to 10-minute checks because she had presented with stable
behaviors/emotions for approximately 2 weeks. Therapist made
this decision after speaking with staff and reviewing written
documentation of Youth A’s behaviors. Therapist’s supervisor (no
longer with the facility) also provided feedback to her about this
decision. Once stepped down, Youth A was allowed to have
different items in her room and staff no longer removed items from
her room. Therapist reported they are developing a safety plan for
school and will not allow communication between Youth A and her
grandparents and sister because of the stress it places on Youth
A. When Youth A returns to the facility, she will be placed back on
five-minute checks and have daily searches of her room and
backpack. Every Thursday there is a team meeting to discuss
youth and all direct staff are required to attend so they are
informed of the safety issues and progress or lack of progress with
Youth A. Youth A has been receiving Dialectical Behavior Therapy
(DBT) and Trauma Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
(TFCBT) and will continue to do so upon her return to the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
5/18/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
being present the morning (5/15/23) Youth A reported to have
slept with a cord around her neck all night. She also reported not
being aware of the situation until Therapist told her later in the
day. She took Youth A to school that morning but did not notice
any bruising on her neck or other parts of her body. She reported
Youth A was wearing a navy-blue hoodie with strings which
covered her neck area. She also reported checking with Youth A
about her goals for the day as outlined in the safety plan for Youth
A. She described her interactions with Youth A and Staff 1 when
attempting to wake up Youth A that morning. Youth A was still
asleep when Staff 2 returned from escorting another youth to
school, so Staff 2 went into Youth A’s bedroom and asked her to
get up before making loud noises to wake her. Staff 2 reported
Youth A was breathing as evidenced by her stomach moving up
and down. Youth A was sleeping in her hoodie and Staff 2 did not
notice anything unusual. Around 7:20am Youth A woke up, ate
breakfast and was taken to school by Staff 2. Staff 2 found nothing
unusual or worrying about Youth A during the morning and trip to
school. Staff 2 also reported never being told to check Youth A’s
neck when doing a room check. When she completed room
checks she would check to make sure Youth A was breathing and
she reported Youth A got her personal items back after the five-
minute check was lifted.
5

Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
5/18/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
not knowing why he was being interviewed but does know and
works with Youth A. He heard that she had wrapped a cord
around her neck but has no details about the incident. He worked
second shift the day (5/14/23) before the report at school and
believes she was acting fine with no issues during the shift. He
reported not knowing if any staff checked her belongings prior to
going to bed or if staff had debriefed with her that evening. He
also reported when doing room checks he will go into the room to
verify the youth is breathing but will not move blankets or check
under them because of privacy for the youth. He does not recall
being instructed to check Youth A’s neck area. He reported
nothing unusual occurred so he had nothing to report to the next
shift but if something had happened, he would have reported it as
required. He also reported conducting variable room checks of five
or ten minutes which ever was required at the time.
Complainant was interviewed via phone, on 5/23/2023. She
reported being the hospital social worker who delt with Youth A
when she was brought to the hospital. She also reported Youth A
informed her the cord was placed around her neck at 8:00pm the
evening before and Youth A reported to have taken it off in the
morning. Youth A also informed Complainant; she had a blanket
pulled up over her neck. Youth A presented with suicidal ideations
and reported to Complainant she will continue to try and end her
life if returned to the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone, on 5/24/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported not knowing
the reason she was being interviewed but she is aware of the
incidents with Youth A. She worked the day before the incident on
5/14/23 and left the facility at 8:15 pm. She also reported Youth A
appeared emotionally stable and was in the milieu working on her
computer when Staff 4 left the unit. The next day she was one of
the staff who picked up Youth A from the school on 5/14/23 at 9-
9:30 am and transported her and Therapist to the hospital. During
the ride to the hospital, Staff 4 asked Youth A if she wanted to talk
and Youth A told her she became triggered after speaking to her
grandfather and sister after Staff 4 had left the unit for the
evening. Youth A informed Staff 4, she had taken her computer
power cord and wrapped it around her neck and slept that way the
rest of the night. Staff 4 reported observing bruising/marks on
Youth A’s neck on the way to the hospital. Staff 4 also reported
staff are required to monitor youth’s emotions and behaviors
6

throughout the day and then record how the youth’s day went at
the end of the shift. Staff should log if the youth has taken their
medication. When Staff 4 engages in room checks she reported
she will complete the checks between five and ten minutes apart
and at variable times. She checks for breathing and now she has
been instructed to make sure Youth A is not wearing a sweatshirt.
Staff 4 also reported she will ask Youth A to show her neck and
have her pull down her blanket if it is over her neck. Staff 4
reported the training staff went over the first situation to help her
understand the extra level of supervision Youth A requires. Staff 4
reported being told by Youth A, that Youth A went to her room
prior to 9:00pm on 5/14/23. Staff 4 shared a belief that youth are
not supposed to engage in bedtime to the scheduled bedtime at
9:30pm. She believes staff are checking on Youth A as required.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone, on 5/24/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being informed
of Youth A’s second self-harming behaviors but not working at the
time. He reported working when the first incident took place on
4/23/23. Staff 1 called him into Youth A’s bedroom saying Youth A
had a cord wrapped around her neck. Staff 5 entered the room
and found Youth A laying on the floor gasping for air. He removed
the cord from her neck and reported it was a computer cord. He
called the supervisor on campus and the on-call supervisors. He
also reported removing all items that could be used for self-harm
when she returned from the hospital (5/1/23) following the first
incident on 4/23/23. He described the precautions required for
Youth A as other staff described and reported Youth A was
removed from some of the precautions a few days before the
second incident. He believed Youth A had been doing much better
until she got her belongings back and did the same thing again a
few days later. He reported he was informed of the new process to
be put into place when Youth A returns. This new process is to
make sure her clothes or blankets are not covering her neck and if
they are he will move the blanket down a little to observe the neck
area. He will continue to check for breathing. He reported feeling
upset that staff did not notice the cord around her neck during the
second incident. He also reported the precaution flow sheet is
used to document room checks.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone, on 5/24/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported not being
present during the first incident but working during the second
incident on 5/15/23. He reported leaving at 10:30pm. He denied
being present when Youth A made a phone call to her grandfather
and sister during the shift. Following the first incident (4/23/23) he
7

understood everything thing that could be used for self-harm was
removed from her room for a period of time. He described the
room checks as turn on the light in the room to look for anything
abnormal and checks are to be variable. He reported he would
wake her up and ask her to remove her blanket or article of
clothing if it was covering her neck. He also reported being told
that other staff do the backpack checks since he normally does
not work the shift she returns from school because he works
Sundays and third shift on Wednesday.
Staff 7 was interviewed via phone, on 5/26/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being aware of
the two incidents with Youth A but not being present for either. He
was working on campus Sunday (5/14/23) the day before the
second incident but not working in the house where Youth A was
lodged, however he did have a short interaction with her in the
house when she was listening to music. He reported she was
listening to a sad song, and he checked if she was feeling all right.
After he left the house, he received a phone call 20 minutes later
informing him Youth A was by road. He responded and when
speaking with Youth A, she informed him she wanted to go for a
walk. He escorted her back to the house. Once at the house he
spoke with Staff 6 and Staff 6 informed him Youth A has not
presented any unusual behaviors at the time, and he informed
Youth A to avoid the road before he left the house. Staff 7
reported stopping at the house before leaving for the day and
when he went into the house, he noticed Youth A was missing
from the milieu. He was informed she had gone to bed and was
sleeping. He did not go to her room to check on her. He also
reported she never spoke about her relatives or appeared upset
when he had interactions with her during the day. He left campus
at 10:00pm and the incident at the road took place around 3-4:00
pm. He reported checking on staff to ensure they are following the
requirements of the precautions and in supervision meetings will
review the video recording to ensure they are completing checks
appropriately. He admitted to not checking the video on that
Sunday but stated he is watching the videos when he works since
the incident. He reported youth are allowed to go to bed if feeling
tired, so he had no concerns Youth A was in bed when he stopped
by the house. He reported team meeting takes place weekly and
each youth is discussed with all staff required to attend in person
or on Teams.
Youth A was interviewed via phone, on 6/1/2023. She is
currently in the hospital awaiting the results of a psychological
evaluation for placement. She reported going back to the facility
8

on 5/22/23 and going AWOL from school yesterday (5/31/23). She
also reported trying to jump in front of a car on the highway before
Law Enforcement showed up and escorted her to the hospital.
She was unable to recall why she took this self-harming action
because everything was good at the facility. She reported staff
were checking on her every 5-minutes and she was always under
supervision. She also reported remembering the first incident that
occurred on 4/23/23 but cannot recall why she tired the cord
around her neck. The second incident on 5/15/23 she
remembered but also does not recall why she tired a cord around
her neck the second time.
Staff 8 was interviewed via phone, on 6/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported working on
5/14/23 in the house with Youth A. He was unable to recall if he
was present when Youth A had a phone call with her family, but
he did give the following report of actions to take if Youth A
becomes dysregulated. If Youth A shows signs of being triggered,
depending on her level of dysregulation, staff are to end the call,
talk with her about her needs, redirect, or call the campus
supervisor or therapist. All the actions taken are to be documented
in the observation log. He also reported checking Youth A’s
backpack, bedroom, and bathroom daily for items she could use
for self-harm. He was unable to recall the level of supervision (5 or
10 minutes) when the incident on 5/15/23 was to have occurred.
School Staff was interviewed via phone, on 6/9/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported school staff
observed bruising on Youth A’s neck at school on 5/15/2023.
Youth A informed the school nurse she had tried to harm herself
with something tied either a rope or computer cord around her
neck. Youth A gave no specific information and never said why
she took this self-harming action, but she never told anyone at the
facility what she had done. The facility came to the school to pick
her up right away after being notified by the school. School Staff
also reported there is a safety plan in place for Youth A when she
is at school. This is the same safety plan provided by the facility.
Youth A had a history of leaving class often, so she was to check
in with the school social worker before leaving.
Documents Reviewed:
Case history: In review of Youth A’s case file the following
information was documented. Youth A was admitted to the facility
on 11/21/22, Youth A first tied a cord around her neck on 4/23/23
and was hospitalized on 4/23/23. Youth A returned to the facility
9

on 5/1/23 and placed on restrictive precautions and a safety plan.
The restrictive precautions were reduced on 5/12/23 and Youth A
reported she tied another cord around her neck the evening of
5/14/23 when she went to school the morning of 5/15/23. Youth A
was re-hospitalized on 5/15/23 and released back to the facility on
5/24/23 at which time restrictive precautions and the safety plan
were reinstated. Youth A was allowed to return to school on
5/25/23 (slight reduction in precautions). Youth A went AWOL
from school on 5/31/23 and hospitalized for the third time the
same day. Youth A was discharge from the facility on 6/1/23.
Residential Initial Service Plan dated 12/22/22 developed for
Youth A. There is a documented history of self-harming behaviors
and suicidal ideation resulting in hospitalization at different times
in her life. Youth A’s fainting was diagnosed as behavioral in
nature and non-epileptic. Numerous triggers regarding her self-
harming behaviors are listed as are her warning signs of the
beginning of her dysregulation. The two pseudo seizures and
fainting spelling she displayed during this reporting period are
documented and she received medical attention. It is also
documented she engaged in two separate self-harming episodes
in which her attempts resulted in superficial cutting. Youth A
reported she was trying to release her frustration. Youth A is
receiving twice weekly individual and/or group therapy, medical,
dental services, and psychiatric medication. The goals identified in
this report are in response to the presenting problems. These
goals include, managing anxiety and depression, improving family
relationships, daily attendance at school, and development of
independent living skills.
Updated Residential Initial Service Plan dated 3/21/23
developed for Youth A. This document outlines Youth A’s
progress in the treatment program from 12/22/22 to 3/21/23.
Documentation indicates, Youth A is struggling to follow through
with her therapy homework and guidance from staff. She tends to
seek a significant amount of attention and expressed suicidal
ideation with no plan. Youth A did engage in self-harming
behaviors on three occasions resulting in no serious injury. Youth
A also engaged in attempted AWOL twice during this reporting
period. Youth A has been visiting with her grandparents both off
campus and through phone calls without emotional dysregulation.
Youth A still struggles with her school attendance and will utilize
the nurse’s office at school seeking medical attention.
Email from Foster Care Worker This email was received on
5/19/23 and in response to the email sent by this writer. Foster
10

Care Worker stated, ‘Thank you for the update. My major concern
is that Youth A was supposed to be checked on overnight every
10 minutes, and if that was occurring how did she sleep the entire
night with a cord wrapped around her neck… also why was a cord
in Youth A’s room at all she had done the exact same thing 2
weeks prior to this current incident. I am concerned regarding the
day-to-day supervision that St. John’s provides.
Clinical Assessment for increased checks dated 5/1/2023 for
Youth A authored by Therapist. The room checks for Youth A
were increased to no more than every five-minutes due to her
recent harm to self and her history of self-harm. This document
outlines Youth A attempted self-harm with a cord around her neck
on 4/23/23 and placed in a psychiatric hospital until 5/1/23 when
she was released back to the facility. The identified trigger to this
action by Youth A is identified as a visit with her grandfather and
younger sister. The type of room check is documented as suicide
risk and self-harm risk. Actions to be taken are as follows; remove
all items from her room that can be used for self-harm and these
items cannot be returned to her room until clinical approval is
given. Five-minute room checks are to be completed when Youth
A is in her room awake and sleeping. Staff are to use the
“Precaution flowsheet” to document their interactions and room
checks and Youth A’s room is to be searched prior to Youth A’s
return to campus. Visits with the grandfather have been
suspended until Youth A is emotionally stable. Youth A is allowed
to continue normal programing if five-minute checks can be
maintained.
Clinical Assessment for increased checks dated 5/12/2023 for
Youth A authored by Therapist. This document outlines room
checks being decreased to every ten-minutes and documenting
Youth A’s activities/interactions/demeanor. The rationale for this
change is documented as Youth A does not need 1:1 supervision
but could benefit from increased support and monitoring because
of recent self-harm. Youth A is no longer considered a suicide risk
but remains a self-harm risk. However, there is nothing indicating
all self-risk items should be removed from her room. Visits with
her grandfather are still suspended and she can attend
programming and merit outing if the ten-minute supervision can be
maintained.
Precautions Flow Sheet dated 5/12/23 for Youth A was
reviewed. This document outlines Youth A will have ten-minute
room checks and will attend school. The reason for the precaution
11

is self-harm risk and suicide risk. The type of check orders is
“eye’s on/arm’s reach” but may be in bathroom with door closed.
Reviewed Safety Plan for Youth A dated 5/1/23 authored by
Therapist. This document outlines the presenting concerns as
intense emotions, a history of self-injurious behaviors, making
suicidal statements, experiencing trauma responses, and
attempting AWOL from campus. The action plan involves ten
items including the following: All staff interviewed indicated they
understood the requirements of the precautions and restrictions
were lifted on 5/12/23.
1. Identify a goal before going to school and review the
outcome before going to bed.
2. Practice a coping skill provided by Therapist and discuss in
therapy.
3. Supervised communication with grandparents.
4. Take a break when feeling overwhelmed.
5. Staff are to engage in daily conversation or check-in-time
with Youth A to process feelings.
6. Youth A will actively participate in treatment plan and follow
house rules and expectations.
7. Youth A will participate in campus activities and avoid
isolation.
8. Youth A will continue to meet with Therapist twice a week.
9. Youth A will continue to be involved in TF-CBT
10. Clinical team will re-evaluate with residential leadership the
need to update the safety plan.
Triggers are documented as family members, bad news, school,
and overwhelming thoughts along with trauma responses.
Coping Skills are documented as going for a walk, spending time
outdoors, cooking, engaging in a task, talking to a trusted adult,
math, belling breathing, blowing bubbles, body scan, tense and
release with playdough, art, and fidgets. The Crisis response is
documented as staff will monitor Youth A and update the clinical
team about any concerns related to her mood and behaviors. Staff
are to engage her in activities (coping skills) and monitor for
triggers. If Youth A is going AWOL, staff should engage in
conversation to deescalate and if she reaches the parking lot, staff
are to engage in a restrictive intervention. Therapist and the
clinical supervisor signed this document.
An unusual event was documented regarding Youth A dated
4/23/2023. This document outlines an event involving Youth A
when she became dysregulated resulting in self-harm. Staff were
completing the 15-minute checks on Youth A between 11:15 and
12

11:30 when Youth A was let into her bathroom when she was
heard coughing. After coming out of the bathroom, Youth A went
to her bedroom and shut the door. Staff 1 knocked on her door to
ask about her wellbeing and Youth A stated she was changing. At
approximately 11:30 to 11:45 Staff 1 knocked on the door and
received no response. Staff 1 entered the room and found Youth
A lying in a prone position on the floor. Staff 1 reported Youth A
coughed and gasped for air every 10 seconds. Staff 1 stayed near

Review of daily observations for Youth A 5/1/23 to 5/15/23.
This document indicates staff were performing variable interval
checks on Youth A no more than every 5 minutes during the time
frame of 5/1/23 to 5/12/23 when the precautions were
“discontinued” by Therapist. This action is documented as having
taken place at 11:30am on 5/12/23 and checks were decreased to

Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation, evidence does
not support staff did not provide for the protection and supervision
of Youth A. There was a precaution put into place which provided
additional supervision; however, it is likely the facility removed the
5-minute checks without fully understanding the intent of Youth A
to engage in self-harming behaviors once gaining the therapist’s
trust.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was recommended, the facility not remove a youth from
precautions until the youth has displayed a significant length of
time without any displays of self-harming behaviors or suicidal
ideation. A two-week period does not appear appropriate given
the nature of the ideation and behaviors. The direct care staff
should also be sought out for feedback since they have daily
contact and need to be the ones measuring the youth’s behaviors.
The decision should be a team decision with all in agreement.
It was recommended the facility develop precautions at the
beginning of a youth’s stay if they have any history of self-harm or
suicidal ideations.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
